repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
## Problem:

`gs` and `g?` are not useful normal commands.

## Solution:

Remove them.

comment_data.body: "normal command" is a pedantic distinction that I don't think is useful to make to users. If the core maintainers don't know wtf "normal command" is then neither will users. We don't need to overshare how everything was implemented internally.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -140,6 +140,8 @@ The following changes may require adaptations in user config or plugins.
 • |nvim_open_win()| now blocks all autocommands when `noautocmd` is set,
   rather than just those from setting the `buffer` to display in the window.
 
+• Removed the |gs| normal command.

comment_data.body: Ditto. Is "normal command" even something that is defined or even mentioned in the documentation?
It's literally on the first page of `:h`

Hmm, you are right. Although I suspect these definitions aren't used that much or consistently in the documentation. "Command-line command" in particular stinks. But if this is the actual definition then I guess that's that.
It turns out "normal mode command" is apparently the real definition 🙄.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -140,6 +140,8 @@ The following changes may require adaptations in user config or plugins.
 • |nvim_open_win()| now blocks all autocommands when `noautocmd` is set,
   rather than just those from setting the `buffer` to display in the window.
 
+• Removed the |gs| normal command.

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
func Test_normal24_rot13()
  " Testing for g?? g?g?
  throw 'Skipped: Nvim has removed g?'
  new
  call append(0, 'abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyzäüö')
  1
  norm! g??
  call assert_equal('nopqrstuvwxyzabcdefghijklmäüö', getline('.'))
  norm! g?g?
  call assert_equal('abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyzäüö', getline('.'))

  " clean up
  bw!
endfunc
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1906,19 +1906,19 @@ func Test_normal23_K()
   bw!
 endfunc
 
-func Test_normal24_rot13()
-  " Testing for g?? g?g?
-  new
-  call append(0, 'abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyzäüö')
-  1
-  norm! g??
-  call assert_equal('nopqrstuvwxyzabcdefghijklmäüö', getline('.'))
-  norm! g?g?
-  call assert_equal('abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyzäüö', getline('.'))
-
-  " clean up
-  bw!
-endfunc
+" func Test_normal24_rot13()
+"   " Testing for g?? g?g?
+"   new
+"   call append(0, 'abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyzäüö')
+"   1
+"   norm! g??
+"   call assert_equal('nopqrstuvwxyzabcdefghijklmäüö', getline('.'))
+"   norm! g?g?
+"   call assert_equal('abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyzäüö', getline('.'))
+"
+"   " clean up
+"   bw!
+" endfunc

comment_data.body:
should we keep a commented-out line here, so that it's obvious to others that a "slot" is available here?

    // OP_XX = 15 /// not used yet
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -80,7 +80,6 @@ enum {
   OP_LOWER        = 12,  ///< "gu" make lower case operator
   OP_JOIN         = 13,  ///< "J"  join operator, only for Visual mode
   OP_JOIN_NS      = 14,  ///< "gJ"  join operator, only for Visual mode
-  OP_ROT13        = 15,  ///< "g?" rot-13 encoding

comment_data.body: Line 525, which refers to `gs`, should go as well.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -515,16 +515,15 @@ gO			Show a filetype-specific, navigable "outline" of the
 
 			Currently works in |help| and |:Man| buffers.
 
-[N]gs							*gs* *:sl* *:sleep*
+								*:sl* *:sleep*
 :[N]sl[eep] [N][m]	Do nothing for [N] seconds, or [N] milliseconds if [m]
-			was given.  "gs" always uses seconds.
+			was given.
 			Default is one second. >
 			     :sleep	     "sleep for one second
 			     :5sleep	     "sleep for five seconds
 			     :sleep 100m     "sleep for 100 milliseconds
 			     10gs	     "sleep for ten seconds

comment_regular_data.body: It's a command, not a "mapping" or "keymap".
What is `:sleep` then? To me that is a "command".
It's a "normal mode command". Isn't Vim great? 😇

# Proposal

https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/13550#issuecomment-2587161138

> Establish `g?` as a "web search" and/or "(local) AI search" command.

Just to note that at the moment "AI search" mappings are paired with "AI edit" mappings. E.g. https://github.com/yetone/avante.nvim provides `<leader>aa` for "AI Ask" and `<leader>ae` for "AI Edit". Both cases bring up a prompt. Not sure if that is inline with what you are suggesting.

title: feat(normal)!: remove the gs, g? normal command
